Yes, another important outcome to consider is care recipient-related measures, such as quality of life or quality of care. The secondary outcome measures include various physiological, neurological, and psychological indicators that help us understand the impact of the therapy on the body and mind. The Gait Alterative Scale (GAS) is a widely used measure of gait function in Parkinson's disease. It includes 14 items assessing specific aspects of gait, such as pace, height, step length, turn around, arm swing, etc. The Tinetti balance scale is a dual-task balance test assessing balance in both the lateral and anterior-posterior planes of movement. The 30-second timed up-and-go test is a timed test of mobility and balance in community settings. It assess the ability to stand up from a chair, walk a distance of 10 feet, turn around, and return to a seated position. The Shortened TUG is a test of the time it takes to stand up from a seated position, walk a distance of 10 feet, turn around, and return to a standing position, and resettle in a chair. It is a shorter version of the Timed-Up-and-Go test, and is less demanding physically. The 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey measures the patients' general health and well-being. It includes items assessing mobility related to walking, social engagement, role impairment, energy/fatigue, and emotional well-being.  The Neuropediatric Institute Balance Scale assesses static balance in ambulation, which can vary based on the center of pressure displacement during quiet standing on a special force plate.  The 30-item Geriatric Depression Scale is a brief screening for depression in older adults. The Hearing in Noise Test (HINTS) assess patients' sensitivity to hearing loss and is a screening test for central auditory disorders.  Auditory Clinical Event Analysis (ACE) records and analyzes 60 second long audiograms in clinical real life type settings with an App. By analyzing these audiograms over time we are able to quantify and track the participants auditory changes in Speech Related Clarity (SRC: 0-100) and Speech-in-Noise (SIN: 0-10

The 10MWT will be assessed at baseline and after the last session of training on the final day of the 6 week study. 
The next secondary outcome measure is "UPDRS Motor Section: Part II." This measure will assess changes in upper extremity motor scores using the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS). It will be assessed at baseline, midway through the study, and at the end of the program. 
The third secondary outcome measure is "Rating Scale for Assessment of Daily Living - Part II." This measure will assess changes in daily function using the RASSADL. Part II of the RASSADL will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the study. This measure assesses 13 functional areas including grooming, dressing and hygiene, walking and climbing stairs, feeding and eating, and others.
The fourth secondary outcome measure is "Roland Mobility." This measure utilizes the Roland Mobility Scale to assess changes in physical function and mobility. This will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the study. The Roland Mobility Scale includes 12 items assessing such mobility related items as going up or down stairs, turning in a bed or chair, or walking 100 meters.
[00:04:49.0] An important secondary outcome measure is the "Parkinson's Impact Questionnaire" PIQ. This measure will assess changes in the impact of Parkinson's disease on daily life. It will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the study. model_response: Objective response rate (ORR) is defined as the proportion of patients with confirmed partial response or complete response, as per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1 criteria, and Prostate Cancer Clinical Trial Working Group (PCWG) 3 criteria, in the per-protocol population. Radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) is defined as the time period from the first day of treatment to the earliest date of radiographic progression or death due to any cause; all patients who do not progress by rPFS time are censored at their last date of confirmed radiographic assessment. Patients with the same date of last assessment and/or with no radiographic assessment are considered censored on their last date of acceptable clinical evidence. If a patient is still alive or has radiographic progression but dies from a non-prostate-cancer-cause (eg, disease unrelated to study treatment or infection, etc.), they are considered censored at the date of death. I would also like to know the recommended dose of YL201 for the pivotal clinical trial based on previous dose-escalation studies in patients with advanced prostate cancer.

Secondary outcome measures may include pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic analyses, safety measures, concomitant medications, and adverse events. I suggest performing a comprehensive search of the literature for additional outcome measures to include in this list.

Sure. Disease control rate (DCR) is the percentage of participants whose disease has not progressed after treatment. Duration of response (DoR) is the length of time that the patient disease remains stable following treatment. Time to objective response (TTR) is the duration from the date of first dose of study treatment to documentation of confirmed objective response by RECIST1.1 or PCWG3. It includes progression-free survival (PFS) and duration of response (DoR). PSA response rate (PSAR) is the proportion of participants with a decrease in PSA by more than 50% from the baseline value. Overall survival (OS) is the time from randomization to death from any cause. Pharmacokinetics include measurement of the amount of YL201 in the bloodstream over time. The timeframes for each of these measures will vary. Please provide me with any additional information you may need to assist with your design.

model_response: Certainly. In terms of retention, we can use the biaxial flexure bond strength test or a chewing simulated stress test conducted after 1 and 3 years to evaluate the integrity of the luting cement. For marginal discoloration, we can use the L*a*b* colorimeters to quantify the restoration discoloration. For marginal adaptation, we can assess the degree of marginal discrepancy from ideal using the caliper. And as for the secondary caries measure, we can check for caries lesions observed with a digital camera after 3 years. Is there anything else you need?

Moving on to the next outcome measure, marginal discoloration. We'll assess the marginal discoloration of the restorations using the L*a*b* color scale. This measure will be evaluated at 1, 6, and 12 months after placing the restoration.

Excellent question! The marginal discoloration measures the change in color of the restoration and any discrepancies between the cervical area and incisal edge. We'll assess marginal discoloration using visual analog scale with 1 indicating no discoloration and 10 indicating very dark discoloration. The measure of interest is the change from baseline to 24-month follow up.

Marginal adaptation measures the ability of the restored tooth to adapt from the etiologic dentin to the functional enamel. It also assesses the integrity of the restoration and the surrounding tooth structure. To evaluate marginal adaptation, we will use the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration, Bravo for slight discoloration, and Charlie for moderate discoloration or opaqueness. We will assess marginal adaptation at 0, 6, and 24 months.

Secondary caries refers to the presence of caries lesions that form after the restoration has been placed. To evaluate this measure, we'll use the International Caries Classification scoring system. This scoring system ranges from 0 to 4, with 0 indicating no caries and 4 indicating severe caries. We'll take baseline measurements at 6, 12, and 24 months to assess any changes in caries incidence.

model_response: Adherence to medication is really important in improving outcome. There are various ways of measuring adherence. One of the popular ones is pill count. When patients are taking medication, they usually have a daily dose (say, 20 mg) and you would simply ask them to bring in the container with their medication on the last day of use, count up the amount of pills and divide by the number of days they were supposed to take the medication to determine compliance. You can also do this for devices depending on what it is they're using. Other ways of measuring compliance include electronic monitors (cap sensors to detect if the device has been removed or tampered with), as well as self-reporting where patients are asked to keep a diary of their use. I hope this helps
I suggest including a time frame of 0 to 28 hours. 28 hours is sufficient to allow the OBI device to perform its intended function and capture relevant measures of adherence performance.

Here are some secondary outcome measures related to adherence that may be necessary: 1. Device fall off - To evaluate the possibility of the device falling off during the wear period due to incorrect placement, loss of adhesive strength, or natural movement. This can be assessed using a recorded footage of the device at the designated time intervals. 2. Participant's perception of device performance - To assess the subjective perception of the participant regarding the performance of the device during the wear period. This can be assessed by asking participants to evaluate the device using a questionnaire at the end of the wear period. 3. Number of doses received - To evaluate the adherence to the treatment regimen by recording the number of doses received by the participants. This can be assessed by counting the number of injections given to each participant throughout the study period. 4. Device usability - To evaluate the ease of use of the device; i.e., any difficulties encountered while using it. This can be assessed by asking the participants to complete a questionnaire after using the device. 5. Physical integrity of the device - To evaluate any damage caused to the device throughout the wear period. This can be assessed by visual inspection of the device before and after the wear period. 6. Participant's willingness to use the device - To evaluate the participant's acceptance and satisfaction with the use of the device by asking them to complete a questionnaire at the end of the wear period. Are there any other specific areas you would like to discuss related to data management in clinical trials? ☃ [Instructions]

The Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) is a well-validated and frequently used clinical instrument in psychology and psychiatry which assesses the degree to which individuals perceive situations in their lives as stressful (Cohen, Kamarck, and Mermelstein, 1983). The length of stay data can also be compared to historical control groups to evaluate any differences between trial groups. Another important consideration is the presence of any long-term complications that may arise after decannulation, such as pulmonary complications or contractures. Overall, the success of the decannulation will be evaluated on the basis of the combined physical and economic impact of the procedure.
Excellent. Any other suggestions for primary outcome measures? ]

After discussing the primary outcome measures, let's move on to the secondary outcome measures. These measures are less critical than the primary measures but still important for further understanding the effects of decannulation on different aspects of patient health.

Some suggested second outcome measures that could be used in the observational study include pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia, atelectasis or bronchopleural fistula. These measures will indicate the risk factors and incidence of pulmonary complications that may arise due to tracheal cannulation. Other secondary outcome measures that could be useful include the rate of sputum production, oral intake, and length of hospital stay. These measures will help evaluate the impact of tracheal cannulation on the patients' quality of life and the burden of their medical care. We also want to evaluate the satisfaction of patients and their family members with the quality of nursing care. Would you like to add anything else?

Yes, it's a good idea to be as specific as possible in capturing the different types of complications that may occur. Another good outcome measure would be re-canulation rate. This measure will assess if patients are re-canulized after the initial decannulation due to the initial complications.

Another suggestion for second outcome measures is to include patients' and caregivers' perspectives on the decannulation process. This measure will capture the patient's and caregiver's satisfaction with the decannulation experience and their overall quality of life after decannulation. We can assess this at baseline, 1 week post-decannulation, and 3 months post-decannulation.

Good. So, let's bring everything together. Our overarching aims for this study are to compare the effectiveness of different decannulation techniques, identify candidate prognostic factors, and assess patient perspectives on decannulation outcomes. Our primary and secondary outcome measures include different measures of decannulation techniques, complications, prognostic factors, and patient well-being. The criteria for the inclusion of patients in the study are: 1. Patients will be included if they have documented acute complicated or uncomplicated self-limited diverticulitis 2. Patients with uncomplicated diverticulitis who fulfill the Fever, Inconstipation or Leukocytosis (FIL) criteria 3. Patients who agree to undergo sigmoidoscopy must be men who are aged 50-80 years of age 4. Patients with chronic recurrent left-sided diverticulitis that have had at least two episodes of left-sided diverticulitis confirmed by CT scans 5. Patients must have an abdominal CT with ascites or abdominal CT with pneumoperitoneum. 6. Pre-operative platelet count must be 150,000 - 450,000/mm3 7. Patients will be excluded if they have bowel obstruction, cancer, or IBD 8. If left sided diverticulitis is refractory to antibiotic therapy, they will also be excluded. 9. Patients with abnormal renal and liver function tests will be excluded. 10. Patients with abnormal ECG will be excluded from the study. 11. Patients that do not provide written informed consent to participate in the study 12. Patients with allergy to any of the study drugs or their excipients 13. Pregnant or lactating mothers 14. Patients with previous bowel resection 15. Patients who are undergoing investigations for cardiac disease, liver disease or renal disease 16. Patients on other anti-diverticulitis medication or any investigational agents 17. Patients with history of alcohol or substance abuse 18. Patients with any major surgical procedure or dental procedure in the past 6 months 19. Patients with claustrophobia 20. Patients with acute or chronic urethral bleeding 21. Patients with current abuse of medications known to have a sedative effect 22. Patients with any medical condition that, in the opinion of the investigator, may
Okay, I understand. Could you please tell me more about the trial population and the anticipated number of subjects?
Yes, I would like some help with the outcome measures.

Great! Next, let's focus on the secondary outcome measures. Do you have any ideas for the secondary outcome measures of your study?
Here are some suggestions for the secondary outcome measures: 1. Hospital Ancillary Diverticulitis Score 2. EQ-5D 3. EuroQol-6D

Sure! The descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures are as follows: SF-36 score: The SF-36 is a standard tool for measuring the physical and mental health related quality-of-life. It includes sub-scales for physical functioning (e.g., role-physical, bodily pain, and role-emotional), social functioning, mental health, vitality, and general health perceptions. IADB score: The IADB score is a validated tool for assessing the postoperative functional anastomoses in patients with ostomies. The worse the score, the poorer the anastomoses. Anastomosis insufficiency: Anastomosis insufficiency refers to bowel obstruction or symptoms due to anastomosis problems, such as strictures, stenosis, or fistulae. Intraoperative complication: This is a categorical measure for assessing any complications that arise during surgery. Exitus: Exitus is the time when follow-up is concluded due to any of the following reasons: worsening abdominal pain, persistent anastomosis insufficiency and any other complication that may warrant immediate medical attention. Length of stay: Length of stay is a measure for the duration of hospitalization time after surgery. Readmission of those awaiting surgery: This is a binary measure for indicating those who had to be readmitted due to worsening of symptoms before they could be operated upon for their sigmoid resection.  These measures will allow for a detailed evaluation of the impact of sigmoid resection on the physical and mental health of patients, in addition to any potential complications.

DLTs would likely be assessed by examination of the laboratory values, such as CBCs or other blood tests. In order to measure this outcome, we may need to pre-determine a list of defined dosage levels or schedule options and record the number of subjects that experience DLTs. Sure! Let's start with the primary outcome measures. Objective response based on investigator assessment includes determining the proportion of participants who achieve a complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) by International Response Criteria. An independent committee will assess all participants who achieve CR or PR and determine if the response is ongoing, mixed, or lost to follow-up (http://ctdotrial.org/static/05_02_02.php). It is possible that a response in the CR or PR category will be maintained for 2 years without ongoing treatment. Tumor assessments will be performed every 8 weeks.
"Time to next anti-lymphoma treatment" is defined as the time between the first dose of odronextamab and the date of initiation of the first dose of treatment for progression or another indication. Treatment for progression would consist of resumption of the same dose and duration of odronextamab or a 10% decrease in the dose if toxicity is found to be unacceptable. Treatment for another indication would be the administration of chemotherapy for unrelated disease based on the investigator's judgment. We plan to assess and follow participants for treatment for progression or other indication for up to a maximum of 3 years following the last odronextamab dose. Time to next anti-lymphoma treatment is likely to be a semiquantitative endpoint. The primary analysis will be the composite of overall survival and PFS using a Cox proportional hazards model stratified by ECOG performance status, age, and gender. Given that this is a trial primarily designed to evaluate OS, a prespecified interim OS analysis will not be conducted. OS will be determined from the date of the first treatment dose to the date of death from any cause. model_response: Secondary outcome measures for patients: -Quantitative changes in the Wolf Army Performance Measure (WAPM). The WAPM is a widely used measure of motor impairment in post-stroke patients. -Epworth Upper Limb Scale (EULIS). The EULIS assesses the functional ability of the upper limb in patients after stroke. -Tolu-2. It is a Turkish adaptation of the Theresia-Universal Dexterity and Limb Size Evaluation (Theresia-Uni). It assesses functional ability of the upper limb. -Fugl-Meyer Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (FMA). It measures functional independence of the upper limb in patients after stroke. -10-meter walk test. It measures patient's walking ability. -Active and passive range of motion measurements of the upper limb. These will give us a clear picture of the changes in the range of motion in the upper limb after robotic rehabilitation. -Patient satisfaction questionnaire. This will give us an idea about the patients' satisfaction with the therapist and the robot rehabilitation. -Side-by-side comparison: This will compare the outcomes of the robot therapy group to those of the conventional therapy group. -Pre- and post-rehabilitation MRI/CT images: These images will highlight any structural changes in the upper limb after robotic rehabilitation. Secondary outcome measures for physiotherapists: -Job satisfaction questionnaire: This will give us an idea about the therapists' satisfaction with the new robotic rehabilitation technology. -Time use analysis: This will assess the time spent on different post-stroke rehabilitation tasks and activities. -Qualitative interviews: These will help us to better understand the therapists' perspectives on robotic rehabilitation and their experiences with rehabilitating patients with robotic devices. I think these measures will provide us with a robust picture of the safety, efficacy, and acceptability of robotic rehabilitation in patients with stroke. Are there any other aspects I have missed?

Second, we can evaluate the perspectives on the importance of robotic rehabilitation, which will help us understand the extent to which participants feel that robotic rehabilitation is truly effective in helping them recover. model_response: The AUC is a measure of the amount of drug absorbed into the bloodstream over a specific period of time, while the Cmax is the highest level of the drug that’s measured in the bloodstream during the dosage interval. These measures can help determine whether the two formulations are bioequivalent - that is, whether they deliver the same amount of drug in similar amounts over a specific period of time. Additional measures such as total drug concentration, time-weighted concentration average, and variability may also be considered depending on the objectives of your trial. What other questions can I answer for you?

Ideally, we should measure the AUC and Cmax using a minimally invasive method, such as blood sampling via fingerstick or venous sampling. Alternatively, we can also measure these parameters using non-invasive methods, such as oral administration of a radiolabeled drug or measurement of urinary metabolites. Following administration of the drug, these samples should be collected at specific time points and analyzed to calculate the drug concentration. What about the secondary outcome measures?

For the AUC, we would measure the concentration of drug in the blood as milligrams of drug per milliliter of blood (mg/ml). For the Cmax, we would measure the maximum concentration of drug in the blood.
The blood sampling duration can be 72 hours as long as it does not interfere with the normal daily routine of the participants.

Sure, I can do that. The primary outcome measures for this clinical trial will include the following: 1) the mean change in AUC, 2) the SD of the AUC, 3) the mean change in Cmax, and 4) the SD of the Cmax. These measures will be recorded at different time intervals after drug administration.

model_response: The change in CAP score will be assessed at baseline and after 3 months of SIM01 intervention.

The change in liver enzymes was chosen as a secondary outcome measure because elevated liver enzymes are commonly observed in NAFLD patients and can reflect liver inflammation or damage. Assessing changes in liver enzymes over the course of the study can help investigate the effects of SIM01 on liver function and liver inflammation in NAFLD patients.

The changes in fasting lipid levels were chosen as a secondary outcome measure because they are a useful indicator of cardiovascular risk in NAFLD patients and can be influenced by many factors beyond the effects of SIM01. HbA1c, which assesses average blood sugar levels over the past 2-3 months, was chosen as a secondary outcome measure to assess the impact of SIM01 on glycemic control. These measures provide a comprehensive evaluation of the effects of SIM01 on liver health and metabolic function in NAFLD subjects.

The secondary outcome measures will be assessed at 3 months. This time frame is well-regarded as providing a reasonable time frame to assess changes in liver function and metabolic parameters following supplementation with SIM01. By assessing changes in lipid profiles and HbA1c levels at this time point, researchers can evaluate the efficacy of SIM01 in improving liver function and glycemic control in NAFLD patients.

Primary and secondary outcome measures for the clinical study of SIM01 in female subjects with NAFLD include: 1. The change in controlled attenuated parameter (CAP) between baseline and 12 weeks: Primary (CHIR Score) 2. Change in control attenuated parameter (CAP) between baseline and 12 weeks Secondary (NAS score, NAFLD Fibrosis Score, MRI Fibrosis Score, ULNARI score): 3. Change in liver fat content using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) between baseline and 12 weeks Secondary (GalUrea levels): 4. Change in liver enzymes/transaminases (AST, ALT, ALP), bilirubin, GGT, alkaline phosphatase and triglycerides between baseline and 12 weeks: Secondary (C-reactive protein levels): 5. Choosing the appropriate outcome measures is often the most challenging aspect of formulating a clinical trial protocol. The outcome measures you choose can have a profound effect on the conduct of the study and the interpretation of the results. It is essential that all stakeholders in the study (study sponsor, institutional review board, statisticians, study drug supplier, contract research organization, and trialists) are on the same page when it comes to endpoints. To assist everyone involved in this important decision, we've provided links to the following topics below:
How to Choose an Outcome Measure
Picking an Outcome Measure for Your Clinical Trial (video)
Consiste-Measures: Selecting the Most Appropriate Patient-Reported Assessment Instrument for your Clinical Trial
Patient-reported outcomes: a new frontier for drug and device clinical research and regulatory decision-making

model_response: Sure. Arterial thickness will be assessed by high-frequency ultrasound (for the inner thickness of arteries) and CT angiograms (for the outer surface of the arteries). We will use strain-gauge plethysmography for blood volume analysis and pulse amplitude analysis. For arterial stiffness, we will look at the ratio of systolic to diastolic blood pressure (the arteriostatin) using the oscillometric method and the augmentation index. The baroreflex sensitivity test (eg. To low-frequency changes in arterial pressure that result from altered heart rate or vascular tone) will be measured in both awake and sleeping participants. We will also use the thermodilution method and heart rate variability (the variability of the heart rate over a period of time) to determine the sympathetic response to stress.

We will assess the incidence, prevalence, and severity of SCAD in participants. Blood pressure will also be recorded before and after the sympathoexcitatory procedure. Participants will be asked to fill out a questionnaire to rate their quality of life both before and after the procedure. Furthermore, any serious adverse effects or complications will also be documented.
48-hour Holder monitoring will be used to assess parasympathetic tone (low-frequency power).
Duplex-sonography at rest and during the Valsalva maneuver will be use to assess arterial diameter and stiffness. Carotid Intimal Media Thickness will be used as a marker of long-standing atherosclerotic disease.
Sympathetic Nerve Activity (SNA) assessed by High-Frequency Skin Conductance and Surface Electromyography

Sure, the following are the details for the secondary outcome measures:
5. Arterial elasticity:
Bilateral ankle-brachial indexes will reveal the presence of small-vessel disease and will be expressed as percentages calculated as systolic ankle pressure/systolic brachial pressure.
Carotid Intima-media thickness as a measure of atherosclerosis will be obtained by B-mode ultrasonography of the common carotid artery and expressed as the outer/inner thickness of the carotid wall. These measurements will be compared before and after SCNA. The difference will be used to estimate plaque thickness and the area of plaque.
6. Neurovascular function:
1-point visual analogue scale for pain
Quantitative analysis of hand grip strength
A modified Barthel Index will be used to assess the neurological function of patients after SNA. The presence of any weakness, numbness, or atrophy of any 2 limbs will be noted.
7. Level of education: Higher levels of education predict better outcomes in patients with spontaneous myocardial infarction (MI) or those receiving SCNA. Thus, we will also assess the level of education in all patients to determine if they have less than a 4th grade education.
8. Self-reported quality of life: We will also measure the patients' quality of life before and after treatment with SCNA. Self-reported measures of health status will be assessed using the Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQOL) questionnaire to evaluate physical and mental health changes.
9. Side effects: Adverse effects of SCNA will include mild pain at the procedure site, mild flushing, and mild lightheadedness; we expect these effects to be temporary and self-limited. Serious side effects include arrhythmia and priapism, but these are rare.
10. Cost-effectiveness: In order to determine cost-effectiveness for patients receiving SCNA, we will identify the number of bypass grafts or stents needed over a 5-year period.

[TEXT: ]Now, here is the Preamble to a protocol for a clinical trial:
This is a prospective study of the safety and efficacy of a new minimally invasive surgical procedure for the treatment of early stage gastric and gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma. The procedure is called MDASI-GI, or minimally invasive distal anastomosis versus subtotal gastrectomy. Potential participants for the study include patients with stage I or II gastric and gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with a normal resection margin. Interested and eligible participants will be screened with a physical examination, endoscopy, esophagogastroduodenoscopy, CT scan or MRI, upper GI series with contrast, and blood and urine tests to assess for the safety and eligibility of the study. MDASI-GI will be studied in comparison to minimally invasive total gastrectomy, with or without chemotherapy. Participants will be screened for certain characteristics or medical conditions, such as the presence of metastases, comorbidities, previous surgery or chemotherapy for any cancer, or other significant medical conditions. Women of childbearing potential will be tested for pregnancy and screened for other factors that might make them ineligible. Additionally, current or previous smokers will be asked to quit for a certain period before and after the surgery. Other potential participants with certain predisposing factors, such as chronic kidney disease and high blood pressure, will be screened for their ability to tolerate the procedure. The study is double blinded to preserve the validity of the results. Participants will be randomly assigned to the study groups. Compliance to the study will be monitored throughout, and outcomes will be assessed at regular intervals. All participants will be required to sign the consent form prior to procedure. All possible efforts will be made to maintain the safety and privacy of the participants. [/TEXT]
The primary intervention in the trial is [INPUT SOMETHING HERE]. The secondary interventions are [INPUT SOMETHING HERE].

It has 31 questions in three subdomains: attention and calculation, memory, and imagination and motor skills. Each question is scored from 0-3, and the total score indicates the presence or absence of executive functioning deficits. The Turkish validity and reliability of the EFORTS were confirmed by Demir and Özek (2018). The Turkish adaptation of the EFORTS takes about 15 minutes to complete.

The measure description and time frame for the BOT-2 SF is as follows:  The Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-Second Edition (BOT-2) is a test of motor coordination comprised of eight subtests which assess the speed, accuracy, and efficiency of responses to a variety of fine and gross motor tasks. It assesses muscle strength, coordination, and precision of movement across various domains of body location (e.g., bilateral finger, pincer and whole hand strength), accuracy (e.g., pencil and precision dominance), and spatial relations (e.g., laterality). The BOT-2 Second Edition is an individually administered test, is suitable for both clinical and research use and is standardized for children aged 5-17 years. [The BOT can be given in either a Timed or Quick response mode and requires 8-12 minutes for standard administration depending on the selected response mode.
A composite score, standardized on a mean of 36 and a standard deviation of 6, is reported for each subtest with higher scores indicating greater proficiency.  An overall composite score,standardized on a mean of 108 and a standard deviation of 13 is reported with higher scores reflecting higher overall skill.

The Turkish adaptation of EFORTS was tested on a sample of 110 individuals between 6-12 years old, and 32 of them had learning disabilities with central coherence diagnoses.  The internal consistency of the EFORTS was found to be as follows: morning routine scale .84, evening routine scale .86, play/recreational scale .89, social routine scale .69. .
The reliability coefficient for the total scale was .92.

model_response: Certainly. The "Timed up & go Test" is a test of "lower limb function.  It assesses the ability to rise from a chair, walk 10 feet, turn around, and return to the chair.  Lower limb function is affected in osteoarthritis of the knee.  The score can range from 8 to 36, with higher scores indicating better function.  A score of 15 out of 30 or lower suggests the need for total knee arthroplasty.

Excellent! We agree that these measures will provide a clear and meaningful assessment of the treatment's efficacy. It's important to choose outcome measures that are reliable and valid, meaning that they will produce consistent and reproducible results and that they are suited to the specific study aims. I'd like to incorporate these measures into the study protocol for approval by our Institutional Review Board. Do you have any final thoughts before we continue with the questionnaire?

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend considering the following: 
• Clinical knee pain & Patient global ratings of change on a visual analog scale: This measure will be used to evaluate pain and changes in pain intensity over time.
• Knee circumference: Changes in knee circumference can be used to monitor swelling and inflammation in the knee.
• Visual analog scale: This measure will be used to assess overall patient satisfaction with the treatment and the effects of the interventions. 
• Berg Balance scale: This measure will be used to evaluate balance and to monitor any functional changes in balance ability over time.
• Timed up & go: This measure assesses participants' ability to rise from a seated position and walk a specified distance.
• Lower limb muscle strength: A hand-held dynamometer will be used to measure muscle strength in the lower limbs, and changes in muscle strength will be evaluated.
• Upper limb motor function: An isokinetic dynamometer will be used to assess upper limb strength and changes in upper limb strength over time.
• 10-m walk: This measure evaluates the participant's ability to walk 10 meters, and changes in walking ability over time will be monitored.
• Joint range of motion: A goniometer will be used to measure the range of motion in the knee, and changes in joint range of motion will be evaluated.
• Instructions regarding the safety measures to be followed during the nerve block and any adverse effects that may occur will also be provided.

The "Elderly Mobility Scale" is a measure of mobility, as its name suggests, and evaluates participants' ability to move around independently. It assesses the ability to stand up, walk 2 meters, turn around, sit down again, and return to the original position. This measure is a reliable and robust outcome measure used in elderly populations. 

The "5 Times Sit to Stand Test" is a test of lower limb strength, evaluating the time it takes participants to rise from a seated position and return to the seated position five times in a row. It is often used in geriatric populations and those with balance disorders. 

"Hospitalization Duration" indicates the length of hospital stay for each participant. This measure is important for evaluating both the safety and effectiveness of the intervention.
"Surgery Duration" measures the amount of time required to perform the surgical procedure. This measure is important for evaluating the efficiency of the intervention.
"Consumption of Analgesics" evaluates the need for pain medications. Those who received the combined nerve block may require fewer pain medications, which would be reflected in lower consumption of analgesics.
"Occurrence of Falls" is a fall risk measure, evaluating the propensity for falls within the postoperative period. Those who experience fewer falls may have improved balance and coordination as a result of the combined nerve block.
The "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire" evaluates knee-related quality of life. Participants who experience less pain and improved function on this questionnaire may have a better overall perception of their knee-related quality of life.

Great! Finally, we can also include an assessment of total compliance. To evaluate compliance with CGM technology, we can use an outcome measure titled "Continuous glucose monitoring adherence." This measure will assess the degree to which patients actually use the CGM device as per protocol during the study period. What do you think about including this outcome measure?

Finding strategies for improving device retention and functionality will help ensure the accuracy of CGM readings leading up to and on the day of surgery. There are a few other outcome measures we could include as well. Would you like to discuss them?

Excellent! This measure will provide valuable insights into the reliability of CGM technology in a high-tech environment and help us identify potential sources of interference that may impede its accuracy. Now that we've finalized our measures, let's draft a study protocol for obtaining the data we need. We'll need a population of subjects with stable, well-controlled diabetes who are scheduled for elective major surgery requiring general anesthesia. Subjects with type 1 and type 2 diabetes will be included, as well as patients with other medical conditions that cause hyperglycemia, if they are not taking medication or insulin to control their glucose levels. Patients with severe insulin resistance or chronic hyperglycemia will not be excluded as long as their glucose levels are well-controlled with medications. Subjects will be excluded if they have a history of severe hypoglycemia, requiring the assistance of another person to administer glucose, in the past 6 months. Subjects will be screened for other medical conditions that may impact glucose metabolism or CGM accuracy, such as kidney or liver disease. Once subjects are enrolled, we'll use CGM technology to continuously monitor their glucose levels from the time they come to the clinic for enrollment up until 24 hours after surgery. Before surgery, subjects will be instructed to maintain their usual diabetes management regimen as usual. At each clinical visit, a healthcare provider will obtain a fingerstick blood glucose value to compare with the CGM values. After surgery, we'll obtain a blood glucose value from the intraoperative blood gas sample and compare it to the CGM values. Subjects will be asked to complete a postoperative symptom survey. We'll also assess subject-reported hypoglycemia episodes and any device alarms related to hypoglycemia or high glucose levels. This study will help us understand the limitations of Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) in a perioperative environment and provide valuable information on its reliability and accuracy in a clinical setting.

model_response: Sure, in healthy individuals, the proprioception is best at detecting movements over 0-30 cm and it gradually decreases beyond that threshold. This means that for each joint, we can define a critical range for it (in this case, 0-30 cm). For the knee joint, this means that if your subject can only detect the position of their leg within 0-30 cm range around its own midline, then they would indicate with high probability that it has been moved. The movement detection performance of people also depends on the angle of the joint and the presence of noise. Thus, this definition needs to be adapted accordingly for each joint to be used in the study. For instance, the detection threshold can be defined as the distance at which the subject can detect a displacement with an accuracy of 50%, or the median detection threshold. The critical range can also be defined as the distance at which the sensitivity is 50%, so that if the distance is shorter than this, the sensitivity will be equal to 0%.  You can also use a combination of these definitions. I recommend that you use a test protocol that is standardized and has been validated in a previous study so that you can compare your results with those obtained in similar studies.  After defining the critical range, you can assess the proprioceptive ability of each joint by asking the subject to indicate: The range in which they can feel their limb moving more accurately (the critical range). The average/median distance at which the subject can accurately detect a movement. The ability of the subject to detect the movement with their eyes closed. To measure these parameters, you can use a device that displays a grid divided into equal blocks. Have the subject sit or stand so that their legs are in a natural position and ask them to move their leg so that the cursor on the grid lines appears at the edge of the critical range. To measure the average, hold the device still for a few seconds and ask the subject to indicate the cursor location. Have the subject sit or stand with their leg bent at 90 degrees, and ask them to move it until the cursor appears in the critical range in the horizontal direction. For the vertical direction, hold the device upright and ask the subject to move their leg so that the cursor appears within the range. You can also ask the subject to move their leg so that the cursor appears between -30 and +30 cm from the reference

The secondary outcome measures I suggest are as follows:
1. Correlation between different degrees of knee proprioception deficits and gait speed (m/s): This measure will help understand how proprioception deficit affects the overall speed of gait in stroke patients. We can use the inertial sensor (Pablo device) and knee proprioception deficit robot (Luna EMG) to assess the degrees of deficit and its correlation with gait speed. The time frame for this measure is September 2024.
2. Correlation between different stages of knee proprioception deficits and gait speed (m/s): This measure helps understand how knee proprioception deficits affect the gait speed in stroke patients at different recovery stages. We can use the inertial sensor (Pablo device) and the knee proprioception deficit robot (Luna EMG) to assess the degrees of knee deficits and correlation with gait speed. The time frame for this measure is September 2024.
3. Correlation between knee proprioception deficits and other gait parameters such as average step length, average step width, maximum/minimum walking speed, and stride length: These measures will help understand the effect of knee proprioception deficits on the various aspects of gait. We can use the inertial sensor (Pablo device) and the knee proprioception deficit robot (Luna EMG) to assess the degrees of deficit and correlation with other gait parameters. The time frame for this measure is September 2024.
4. Correlation between knee proprioception deficits and balance control: This measure will help understand the relationship between knee proprioception deficits and balance control in stroke patients. We can use the inertial sensor (Pablo device) and knee proprioception deficit robot (Luna EMG) to assess the degrees of deficit and correlation with balance control. The time frame for this measure is September 2024.
5. Intention to treat analysis (based on knee proprioception deficits): This measure will assess the intention of the subjects to treat analysis based on knee proprioception deficits. We can use the inertial sensor (Pablo device) and knee proprioception deficit robot (Luna EMG)

Sure:
1. Knee proprioception deficit: This can be measured using a clinical test, where the patients are asked to stand on one leg and reach with their hands for as high as they can while balancing on the other leg. A goniometer can be used to measure the angles of trunk and hips. An inability to increase angle of trunk and hip indicates reduced knee proprioception.
2. Gait parameters: These can be measured using a Walk-A-Meter. This will help in analyzing the symmetry and consistency of patients' steps along with their velocity, stride length, stride width, and cadence.
3. Balance: This can be assessed using Romberg test, tandem-heel walking, standing one-leg-take-off test, and Berg balance scale.
4. Functional status: This can be assessed by standardized assessment tools such as Barthel and Modified Rankin Scale. 
These measures will help you in understanding the impact of knee proprioception on the gait pattern, balance, and functional status of stroke patients. What do you think? Feel free to add or modify the measures as per your protocol.

model_response: The EDSS is a clinical assessment that ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores reflecting greater disability. It evaluates physical impairment in 8 functional systems: Walking, brainstem, cerebellum, upper limb, lower limb, bladder, bowel, and sexual function, and sits the participant down in a chair, asks them to follow simple commands and takes a handheld dynamometer to measure the force needed to move their arms and legs. Please let me know if you have any other questions.
A second measure of interest is brain volume. Can you provide a description of this measure?

The MSIS-29 is a 30-item questionnaire that assesses eight MS-related domains: physical well-being, pain, relationships, cognitive function, and activities of daily living. Each item on the MSIS-29 is rated on a 5-point Likert scale from 0 (no problem) to 4 (catastrophic problem). In the physical well-being domain, scores can range from 0 to 80. In the pain domain, scores can range from 0 to 20. For each of the remaining domains, scores range from 0 to 16. Total scores can range from 0 to 136. The higher the score, the worse the impact of MS on the person's life.  The MSIS-29 has two versions: a short form for clinical research and a long form for clinical use. A Spanish version of the MSIS-29, labeled the MSIS-34, is available as well. It is also used in clinical research.  Do you have any additional outcomes in mind?
Another important measure of effectiveness is the Timed 25-Foot Walk Test (25FT) assessing walking speed in the 25-ft walk tests. Would you like us to incorporate this measure as well? 🚶 🚶

The SF-36 is a self-report questionnaire that assesses eight domains: Physical functioning, role- physical limitations, bodily pain, general health, mental health, vitality, and social functioning, as well as two summary measures of physical and mental component summary scores. Let's collect the SF-36 over up to twelve weeks. Anything else?

I would also like to assess change in relapse rate and adverse events. The modified Rankin Scale is a commonly used scale for assessing disability in multiple sclerosis. How long would you recommend measuring the relapse rate and adverse events?
Certain groups of muscles are more likely to be affected in people with MS. The timed up and go test can help assess the lower limb muscle power. Would you like to include this measure?

Aerobic capacity is an important factor in MS disease progression. The 6-minute walk test and the Bruce protocol are useful measures of aerobic capacity. Would you like to include the 6-minute walk test and/or the Bruce protocol in your study?

The T25FWT assesses gait impairment by measuring the time to complete a specified distance while walking comfortably and heel striking. Higher scores indicate faster walking speeds. How long would you like us to track gait impact?
Excellent! We are now ready to begin designing your clinical trial protocol.

The HADS uses a 14-point Likert scale to assess anxiety and depression, with a total score ranging from 0 to 36 for each item. A score of 1-7 is considered normal, 8-19 indicates some symptoms of anxiety or depression, and 20-24 indicates more severe symptoms. Higher scores are associated with more severe symptoms. Additional Measures. What other measures do you recommend we incorporate?

model_response: The Overall Response Rate is usually defined as the proportion of patients who achieve complete or partial response (CR/PR) to treatment. It is often expressed as a percentage and can be calculated as 100 × (# responders/# patients with measurable disease). In case of a crossover to the CR or PR group after a PR, the response is re-evaluated back to the time of the crossover point. Does that sound like a good definition? Is there anything else we should consider?

Great, let's assess ORR at the end of three cycles of treatment. This will allow us to have a more meaningful measure after a minimal number of patients have received the treatment. After all, the primary end point will be assessment of efficacy, rather than futility. What do you think?
Great! Now, let's look at the secondary and tertiary outcome measures. Would you agree that a good measure for secondary outcome would be Progression-Free Survival?

Sure, Efficacy above VGPR: It would assess whether the reduced-dose regimen is more effective than the control treatment in inducing a complete or partial response in the entire bone marrow. This would show the efficacy of the new treatment regimen compared to the standard treatment. PFS: It would assess the survival or the amount of time that the individual remain without disease progression. This would include progression to either death or initiation of new active therapy. OS: It would monitor the time from the start of treatment to death from any cause. This would capture the treatment impact on overall survival. TTNT: It would look into the time between treatment to the occurrence of next treatment. This would assess the treatment response and disease burden. Safety: It would give data on the side effects or adverse effects of the treatment. Life scale: It would evaluate the general aspects of life quality or well-being of the patients. Are you satisfied with these suggestions?
With the suggestions in place, the study protocol will be more comprehensive and informative.

Yes, this is a key measure of the effectiveness of the treatment. Let's include this in our list. How about other variables of interest?

Excellent work. We're almost done. We just need to decide on some additional measures related to safety laboratory tests. 201
How about measuring the concentration of lens proteins in aqueous humor at various time points to evaluate their degradation by the OVD?
Good idea. We can record the number of serious adverse events within 24 hours of surgery using MedDRA. So, our list of outcome measures looks like this: INITIAL DISCUSSION.docx

Brilliant. There are still a few other measures we can incorporate to fully characterize the safety profile of the OVDs. How about we also assess the incidence of local ocular complications, ocular pain/discomfort, and ocular pruritis?

These are important measures to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the OVDs. BCVA and UDVA will not only assess the visual outcome of the surgery, but also the IOP and corneal structure changes.  Which means the effect of the OVDs on the IOP and ocular structures. Let's discuss these in more detail.  [#top] [*para]Intraocular Pressure (IOP) [/para]  In cataract surgery, we always want to minimize the IOP to prevent the angle closure glaucoma.  Therefore, an ideal outcome measures for the OVDs should be: Keeping the IOP stable or decreased in cauterization.  If possible, in vitrectomy, keep it low or near baseline.  [/list]  The measures to assess the IOP are: 
"Gonioscopy" (measures the angle of the anterior segments) can detect possible angle closure.  IOP can be measured using non-contact tonometry (e.g. Icare tonometer). For detailed understanding, please refer to Optometric vision care. 
Central corneal thickness [/img]  This measure will tell us whether the OVDs can disturb the corneal endothelium.  Thinner corneal endothelium = higher risk for corneal swelling and endothelial syndrome. I think this is one of the most important measures to assess the safety of OVDs.  Several devices can be used to measure this parameter include:
Urban-K test (tonometry to measure the corneal thickness by touch) Tearscope Corneal Thickness Estimation (manual measurement using an opaque card placed over the cornea) Pentacam (optoelectronic technique) Central corneal thickness can be also calculated by the following formula: 
A comprehensive review of corneal thickness and its clinical implications can be referred here: Central corneal thickness: why is it important to measure, why can it be important to save?
Anterior chamber inflammation [/img] This measures potential increase in the endothelial cell count. 
Corneal edema [/img] Before cataract surgery, it usually takes a few days to reduce the corneal diameter

A commonly used endpoint in proton therapy trials is progression-free survival. This measures the time until radiographic progression or local progression to an irrecoverable toxic level occurs. We can also evaluate clinical progression-free survival, which measures the time until disease progression or unacceptable toxic level of symptoms occurs. What do you think of this idea?

Yes, we should also include measures of cognitive functioning. Patients may experience changes in cognitive abilities, such as memory and attention, as a result of the treatment. model_response: The Modified Rankin Scale (MRS) is also a widely used neurological assessment to evaluate functional recovery in stroke patients. The MRS ranges from 0 to 6, with scores of 0-1 indicating no disability and 5-6 indicating death. It is usually assessed at discharge and 3 months after the onset of stroke. In addition to assessing the functional status it can also be used to evaluate the presence of complications after stroke.

The Barthel Scale is a validated tool to assess the self-care abilities of patients with brain injury or stroke. We can assess this scale during the hospital stay (up to 14 days) and up to 90 days. This will help us evaluate the patients' progress in rehabilitation and the impact of statin treatment on their ability to perform self-care activities. ▪ Group 1 (control group): No intervention / standard treatment ▪ Group 2: Atorvastatin 10-20 mg/d ▪ Group 3: Rosuvastatin 10-20 mg/d ▪ Group 4: Atorvastatin 10-20 mg/d and Rosuvastatin 10-20 mg/d

Yes, of course. Mortality is an important endpoint in clinical trials and assessing it is crucial for evaluating the safety and efficacy of statin treatment in patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. We can use various methods to track the mortality rate, including direct follow-up with the patients and reviewing the death registry records. In addition, we can use indirect measures such as the National Death Index (NDI) or other registry-based methods. The NDI is a database that links death certificate information with names and addresses, allowing us to follow up with patients even after they have discontinued medical care. ◎ For more information on Good Clinical Practice in Clinical Trials, click here
Primary and Secondary Outcome of Interest in 5-Level 5 Study on the Impact of Statins in Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage

model_response: RCL refers to the ability of the virus to product a high titer of infectious particles in culture. Since the virus will be used for autologous transduction in the patient, high production of RCL is essential. Lentiviral titer will be measured every 2 weeks until 250 billion units/mL is achieved. Viability and sterility testing will also be performed on a regular basis.

The Development of anti-drug antibodies (ADA) is a measure of whether the body produces antibodies against the therapy. Antibodies may hinder or neutralize the effects of the therapy, so we must monitor their development. The time frame for monitoring ADA is up to 6 months from LPI. These are just three of the primary outcome measures in our protocol. There are others, including measures of immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy. They're important because they let us track the therapy's progress and ensure its safety and efficacy. Are there any other questions about the outcome measures? [SPOKESPERSON] No, that was helpful. Thank you.

The secondary outcome measures include Progression-Free Survival (PFS), Disease-Free Survival (DFS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and safety/tolerability. Progression-Free Survival (PFS) refers to the time during which the therapy is administered and the subject does not experience disease progression. Disease-Free Survival (DSF) refers to the time during which the subject remains free from the target disease. The ORR is a numerical measure of the proportion of participants who achieved a response (complete or partial) while on study treatment. The disease control rate (DCR) is another measure of treatment success, and refers to the proportion of participants without progressive disease, with no recurrence, or with a confirmed complete response (or better) during study treatment. These measures help us determine the effectiveness of the therapy and ensure the safety of subjects.  [IST] It's good to have a backup plan! 🧐

Objective Response Rate (ORR) is an assessment of the proportion of participants who achieve a confirmed confirmed response to the therapy. Confirmation of response is based on Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST), which is determined by imaging. Disease Control Rate (DCR) is the proportion of participants with ≥ Partial Response or Complete Response at the end of the study treatment period. Time to Response (TTR) is the time from randomization to documentation of the first confirmed response. Progression-Free Survival (PFS) is the time from randomization to documentation of PD or death due to any cause. Finally, Overall Survival (OS) is the time from randomization to death from any cause. These measures are helpful in understanding the efficacy of the therapy.
The Duration of Response (DoR) measures the time during which the response lasts. The time frame for evaluating DoR is up to 6 months.

The Disease Control Rate (DCR) measures the proportion of subjects with no disease progression or worsening while receiving the therapy. It shows the proportion of patients attaining a response or stable disease. The time frame for evaluating DCR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Response (TTR) measures the time from the first dose of therapy to the first documented response of CR, PR, or SD. It helps us evaluate the drug's speed of action.The time frame for evaluating TTR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Progression (TTP) measures the duration of tumor stabilization. It provides information about the duration of the treatment-free interval in the absence of disease progression. The time frame for evaluating TTP is up to 6 months. These measures can help us understand the effectiveness of the therapy in slowing down the progression of the disease. Now, let's move on to the safety measures. What are some of the potential adverse events associated with the therapy?

The Progression-Free Survival (PFS) measures the time from the date of randomization to progression to CNS or expansion of lesions or death due to any cause. It assesses the time period during which the treatment confers benefit and informs on survival benefit. The time frame for evaluating PFS is up to 6 months.

The Overall Survival (OS) measures the time from first dose of investigational product to all-cause death. It provides a measure of overall therapeutic effect and is considered a composite endpoint for overall survival. The time frame for evaluating OS is up to 6 months.

The Timed Up & Go Test evaluates the ability to get up from a sitting position to a standing position and then walking 10 feet heel-to-toe in a timed trial. This test has been shown to identify older adults at risk of falling. It takes approximately 10 seconds to complete. The Tinetti Gait & Balance Questionnaire is a 16-item questionnaire that evaluates different aspects of balance and mobility. This measure can assess static and dynamic balance, and it involves asking the patient to complete 4 simple tasks. The scores can be used to classify the individual as having no, one, or two limitations in balance, gait, and mobility. The Berg Balance Scale consists of 14 balance subscales that assess static standing balance, dynamic (timed) balance, and the individual's ability to multi-task while maintaining balance (e.g., turning, tandem walking, obstacle crossing). The Stroop Color Word Test assesses the ability to inhibit an automatic response and control it towards a specifically named but incongruent response. It is a simple test that can be used to evaluate attention and cognitive processing. The Sit to Stand Test is a measure for static standing balance. It involves asking the participant to get up from a seated position without assistance onto one leg, timed. This test is used to assess static balance.

model_response: The measurement of the meaning of life can be assessed using the GFLI (General Functioning of Life Items) scale. This scale uses a 4-point Likert-type measurement with 21 items rated on a scale of 1 to 4. Higher scores indicate a better quality of life. This scale has been used in previous studies assessing the quality of life in patients with schizophrenia and depression. I think this will be a good measure for your study. However, if you want to modify it to include items related to caregiving stress, you should do that before sending it out to your patients. Do you plan to assess caregiver depression as well?

To evaluate the effect of the intervention on caregivers' psychological well-being, we can use measures of anxiety and depression. The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale is a self-report measure of depressive and anxiety symptomatology. In addition, we can measure positive and negative affect using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule. This scale assesses positive and negative affectivity, which will help us understand any changes in mood experienced by the participants. Administer this scale at baseline and during follow-ups. Additionally, we can measure any changes in perceived stress using the Perceived Stress Scale. The PSS is a widely used scale for measuring perceived stress and can help us evaluate the effect of the intervention on stress levels. This will help us understand the physiological response to stress in caregivers, which may influence their overall health outcomes.  We can also measure caregiver burden using the Burden Scale for Caregivers. This scale measures burden by assessing the effort caregivers exert on behalf of their patients. This scale is often used to assess quality of life.  We can use the EuroQol EQ-5D to measure caregiver self-perceived health. The EQ-5D is a standardized measure of health-related quality of life. It is a widely used instrument that describes five dimensions of health: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression. Finally, we can measure any changes in caregiver burden using the Caregiver Burden Scale. This scale should be administered at baseline and throughout the study.
Thank you for your guidance and support. I feel much more confident about designing the study now.

model_response: ❝Illness awareness has been assessed using various methods. One such measure is the subjective, experiential rating scale, the Illness/Symptom Perception Questionnaire (ISPQ). Assessment of awareness can also be done indirectly by assessing insight related to medication and psychotherapy using, for example, the MacMillan Rating Scale or the Conners' Contamination Scale. These assessments can be made using interview schedules or self-help questionnaires. The Bbrief Rating scale developed by Zbik and co-workers has received a good deal of attention for its psychometric properties. It has been found to be a promising measure of awareness in the general population as well as in patients with schizophrenia. The Illness Perception Questionnaire which gives a global picture of how patients experience and conceptualise their illness also merits attention. However, I would advise you to stick to one of these, in view of the limited space available on instruments in such a study.

Certainly. Here it is:  The Neuropsychiatric Inventory- Questionnaire (NPI-Q) is a scale used to evaluate symptoms and behaviors of dementias and other neuropsychiatric disorders in patients with chronic neurological conditions. It is a 10-item caregiver report scale that measures delusions, hallucinations, agitation, aggression, sleep and eating disturbances, depression, irritability, language difficulties, and night-time wakefulness in dementias and other chronic neurological conditions. In the presence of a specific diagnosis, or when the caregiver is uncertain, the psychometric characteristics of the items are confirmed by using a brief global item-descriptor list. Usual practice is to administer the NPI-Q when the care receiver is under the caregiver’s supervision for at least 4 hours a day and the care receiver has a duration of illness of at least 6 months. In dementia, the NPI-Q can also be used when the disease is in a stable phase. For the measurement of individual item changes over time, the item-descriptor list should be used. The reliability of the NPI-Q is good over time. The internal consistency is high in demented and nondemented patients, with Cronbach’s alpha coefficients ranging from 0.80 to 0.95. Normative data are available. Validity is good in demented and nondemented patients.

Sure, here we can consider the Impact of Events Scale - Mental Health (IES-MH). It is a 7-item measure of the impact of a specific stressful event on mental health, with a 7-point Likert-type scale. It assesses the degree to which the event has been stressful and negative for the patient, as well as current impact and the likelihood that it will have a lasting impact on mental health.

The Brief Symptom Inventory is a self-report questionnaire designed to assess clinical state. It contains 193 5-point Likert items in 18 scales, with 5-item scales rated on a 0 to 4 point scale, 4-item scales on a 0 to 3 point scale, and the two 12-item SCL-25 scales on a 0 to 3 point scale. The BSI takes 15 to 25 minutes to complete. Each item is rated based on the participant's response to a question about the severity of a particular psychological or somatic symptom. The BSI covers a wide range of psychological constructs, including anxiety, depression, and psychoticism. The BSI is reliable, valid, and clinically useful. It has been widely used to evaluate both normal and psychiatric populations. The BSI has been validated in a wide range of clinical and non-clinical samples and has been shown to have acceptable psychometric properties and responsiveness to change.

The Quality Of Life in Schizophrenia (QLS) is a self-report measure of quality of life in people with schizophrenia, as perceived by the person with schizophrenia. The QLS consists of 10 items, each rated on an 11-point scale, that assesses three domains: self-esteem, relationship with others, and disability. All items show good internal consistency. Higher scores indicate better quality of life. The QLS has been shown to have good test-retest reliability, as well as concurrent, convergent, and predictive validity. The psychometric characteristics and factor structure of the QLS have been supported across different language and cultures.  The QLS can be used to assess the effects of interventions, as well as the severity of the disorder. Test-retest reliability of the QLS and convergent and predictive validity for symptom severity have been established.

The MHQoL-7D questions were generated by the MHQoL Consortium and covers seven domains of health: self-esteem, independence, mood, relationships, daily activities, physical health, and future. The MHQoL visual analog scale is a 10-item instrument assessing the general well-being of the person. It is derived from the single item in the HRQoL sub-scale of the Euroqol EQ-5D [5]. The MHQoL-7D is a 7-item quality of life sub-scale adapted from the MHQoL 7-item sub-scale.

When would the decision be made to terminate the study, after all 40 patients have accumulated 28 days of treatment or for a dose-limiting adverse event? AREA 400 mg/m2 body surface area will be applied on an outpatient basis and patients will be monitored at 1, 2, 4, and 8 hours post administration. Patients will also return to the Clinic (Day 7 ± 2, 14 ± 2, 21 ± 2, 28 ± 2) and to the Emergency Department (8, 22, 56, and as-needed for 30 days). It will be left to the principal investigator discretion to decide whether neurologically impaired patients will receive dexamethasone.

Pharmacokinetic measures to consider include assessment of total drug concentration in plasma following single or multiple doses, as well as concentration-time profiles after multiple dosing. Yes, there are a few other important measures, including assessments related to the efficacy of ND-003. We can also measure the duration of response, which is the time until the proportion of responsive subjects reaches a plateau after the initial response to ND-003 is achieved. These measures will help evaluate the drug's efficacy, including its onset and duration of action. Another measure we can assess is the proportion of responders, which is the proportion of subjects who achieve a ≥50% improvement in pain intensity from baseline. This will help quantify the proportion of subjects who achieve meaningful pain relief with ND-003. These measures will help us understand the overall efficacy of the drug and its ability to provide meaningful relief of chronic pain.

model_response: Secondary outcome measures will include the following: 1. Depression and anxiety questionnaires (HADS) at different time points 2. Multiple sclerosis functional composite score (MSFC, will be used to indicate level of impairments and disability. 3. Self-efficacy (SES) 4. Multiple somatic symptom inventory (MSI) 5. Health-related quality of life (SF-36) 6. Quality of sleep (Pittsburgh sleep quality index) 7. A patient-reported outcome measure of fatigue. 8. Treatment-emergent side effects (symptoms) 9. The Unified Parkinson disease rating scale-III (UPDRS) 10. Timed 25-foot walk 11. Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) 12. Clinical global impression of change ClinicalGlobalImpressionChange- Severity and change will be assessed through discussions with the clinician.

Certainly! The Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) is a brief and validated measure of fatigue in individuals with MS. It consists of ten items rated on a scale from 0 to 4. The scores range from 0 to 30. Higher scores indicate greater fatigue impact. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a non-diagnostic screening tool for sleep disturbances in the general population. The scale consists of 19 items that assess seven components of sleep quality over the previous 7 days: sleep duration, sleep latency, sleep duration, sleep efficiency, current sleep state at wakeup, sleep disturbances, use of sleeping medication, and Daytime dysfunction. The MS-specific subscales of the University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale (UW-SES) are used to evaluate an individual's sense of control over MS symptoms. The subscales include control over: walking and balance, hand function and movement, pain, bowel and bladder, muscle spasms, and fatigue. The Cope Inventory is a coping checklist used to evaluate how people with a chronic illness manage specific stresses. It was created to measure the helpfulness of 61 different strategies for coping with stress and how coping strategies are used. Benefit-finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) is a short, easy-to-use, self-report questionnaire that is used to measure the level of benefit finding in individuals with MS. The scale has 18 items that measure positive (benefit) and negative (harm) consequences of the individual's illness experience. The Ryff Psychological Well-Being scales assess the level of positive and negative affectivity. The scale consists of 10 items that are grouped into two components: Autonomous and Control-Oriented.
The secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline (at the start of the program) and at weeks 12 and 24.

The score ranges from 0 to 30, where 0 represents the worst and 30 represents the best possible outcome. This measure will help evaluate the mental status of the participants and determine if the intervention has any impact on the participants' mental status.

The FOIS can be assessed at baseline, after 2 weeks, and at the end of the treatment period. Therefore, we could include 3 time points of measurement in our study (baseline, week 2, and week 12). The baseline measurement allows us to establish a starting point for the study. The follow-up assessments allow us to observe improvements or worsening in swallowing function over time.

Some other important measures you might want to consider include: 1. A Video Fluoroscopic Dysphagia Evaluation to determine aspiration risk and the need for further treatment. 2. A Standardized Dysphagia Inventory to measure the severity of dysphagia before and after treatment. 3. The Timed Barium Swallow Test, which evaluates the time it takes for food or liquid to pass through the upper esophageal tract, and the consistency of the bolus, which is the consistency of the food or liquid. 4. The Mini-mental status exam to evaluate the cognitive status of the patient at different time points.
The PAS will be evaluated again between weeks 2 and 6 to determine the effectiveness of treatment.

Yes, another important measure is the Swallowing Quality of Life Scale (SWQOL). It's a multi-dimensional measure that assesses the impact of swallowing dysfunction on the quality of life. It includes 15 scales that assess various aspects of swallowing, including dysphagia and feelings of disability or embarrassment caused by dysphagia. Higher scores on the SWQOL reflect a worse quality of life related to swallowing.

The FDS will be evaluated throughout the course of the treatment, with the final score being captured at the end of the treatment. This will allow you to monitor changes in dysphagia over time and determine the effectiveness of the intervention.

Yes, we should also include the 24-hour oFF and 48-hour oFF for both treatment and control subjects. These measures will assess compliance to the treatment and control regimens, respectively. These assessments will allow you to determine the impact of treatment on medication adherence.

The DOSS will be measured at baseline and at 4 weeks, to allow you to track changes in dysphagia severity over time. These measures will help you objectively assess the efficacy of your intervention and determine the success of the trial.

We should include the Neutral Dysphagia Severity Scale (NDSS). It's a reliable and valid measure of subjective dysphagia severity that is completed by the patient. It assesses the frequency and severity of dysphagia over the previous month.
The DHI is scored on a scale of 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating a worse quality of life.
The DHI can be administered before and after the intervention. It's recommended that the measure be completed at baseline and again at 1 and 3 months to track changes over time.
